Lesley’s Readers: Mad about the Boy by Helen Fielding

Written by Sarah Jenkins · Published Jan 27, 2014

Sarah Jenkins’ review:

What do you do when a girlfriend’s 60th birthday party is the same day as your boyfriend’s 30th? Is it wrong to lie about your age when online dating? Is it morally wrong to have a blow-dry when one of your children has head lice? Does the Dalai Lama actually tweet or is it his assistant? Is technology now the fifth element? Or is that wood? Is sleeping with someone after 2 dates and 6 weeks of texting the same as getting married after 2 meetings and 6 months of letter writing in Jane Austen’s day?

Pondering these, and other modern dilemmas, Bridget Jones stumbles through the challenges of single-motherhood, tweeting, texting and rediscovering her sexuality in what SOME people rudely and out-datedly call ‘middle age’.

Reserve Bridget Jones: Mad about the Boy by Helen Fielding from our libraries.

If you enjoyed Bridget Jones: Mad about the Boy by Helen Fielding you might like:

  • How to fall in love by Cecelia Ahern
  • Sense & sensibility by Joanna Trollope
  • The proposal by Tasmina Perry

Sarah Jenkins

I contribute to Lesley's Readers.
